page_analysis.text_content:
Attic
space &
equivalen-
cies

Attic, closet, & perimeter spaces

On all accessible floors, areas with at least 5' of head clearance count toward the gross
floor area regardless of the floor plan or actual usage of the space.

Voluminous spaces in a
structure contribute to
the mass even if these
areas are not used
or described in the
floor plan. The 2nd &
3rd floor equivalency
addresses how these
areas count toward the
gross floor area.

In Fig 11 below, the highlighted areas count as follows:

• Area A of this 3rd floor (accessible via stairs), has 5' of head
  clearance and counts as 3rd floor area.
• Area B of this 2rd floor (accessible via stairs), has 5' of head
  clearance and is included in the count of the, more obvious, 2nd
  floor area.

Note: 500 sf of unusable attic
space may be exempted for
Category 1 & 2 historic homes.

Note:
Measurements are
from top of floor to
underside of the rafter

Fig 11 Attic, closet, & perimeter spaces

visual_elements.description: A cross-section diagram of a house, labeled 'Fig 11 Attic, closet, & perimeter spaces'. It illustrates how spaces with at least 5' of head clearance are counted towards gross floor area. The diagram shows a foundation, a 1st floor, a 2nd floor, and an attic space under a pitched roof. A staircase provides access between floors. Two areas are highlighted with hatching: 'Area A' is the central portion of the attic, designated as 3rd floor area. 'Area B' is a perimeter space on the right side of the 2nd floor, situated under the sloped roof. A vertical dimension line on the left side indicates a height of '5'' from the floor to the sloped ceiling. Callout lines point to various parts of the structure, with labels on the right side being partially cut off. The label 'cc' is near the stairs.
visual_elements.location: Center of the page, below the main text and bullet points.

additional_notes.note: The page layout includes a dark grey vertical sidebar on the left with white text.
A key rule is highlighted within a light grey box at the top of the main content area.
There are two separate 'Note' boxes with dark grey backgrounds and white text. One provides an exemption rule for historic homes, and the other clarifies measurement points.
Text labels on the right side of the diagram are partially cut off due to the edge of the page. Visible fragments include 'Underside of', 'pical)' (likely 'typical'), and 'oor' (likely 'floor').
The text 'cc' appears in a handwritten style near the stairs in the diagram; its meaning is not defined on the page.
The page number '16' is located at the bottom left of the page, below the sidebar.

cross_references.description: Refers to the diagram on the current page.
